Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2010 12:12PM bonnie1jean wrote: Definitely have the slides read at another facility.  I had my slides read at two other facilities besides the one that did the original reading.  One facility read the grading slightly higher, but since the other two both read it lower, the medical  oncologist felt comfortable going with the lower reading, especially since one of the lower readings came from a major cancer center here in New York.  I think it's great to hear from a husband on this forum. Good luck to both of you.
Posts.Title: Posted the on another forum, 3 pathologists 2 opinions? Lesinindy SeasideMemories

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2010 12:11PM bonnie1jean wrote: Trying to decide what to do with DCIS is so difficult.  On the one hand they are telling you it is Stage 0 and not life threatening and then in the next breath they are saying it has the potential of becoming invasive and they have no way of knowing with whom it will and whom it won't.  It kind of sounds like it's a crapshoot at best.  I've gone for several professional opinions and have heard everything from "if it were me I would have a mastectomy", to "you can just be monitored closely" and in between that I've been told to have radiation, not have radiation, take Tamoxifen, don't take Tamoxifen.  Since my diagnose was DCIS vs. Pleomorphic LCIS, I am awaiting results from further pathologic testing before making my decision.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2010 02:08PM - edited Jan 16, 2010 02:12PM by bonnie1jean I am a very strong believer in stress being the cause of major illnesses.  I was just diagnosed in December 2009. For the last  3 years I have been under tremendous stress.  Three years ago my mom, who was my best friend, became very ill and suffered horribly for 4 months before passing away.  It was the worst time of my life.  Then to add to the stress, my boss has continuously done despicable things to me, making my work life an absolute nightmare.  I only continue to work there because of the bad economy and poor job market.  He has more mood swings than a woman with PMS.  When I was diagnosed I said to everyone that if there is one absolute cause for this, I would have to say it is the stress of working for this man.  Also of note is that 18 months ago I developed high blood pressure which I am sure was brought on by stress.
